name: Kepler-175
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-175 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-175 is a star with 0.9620000000000001 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.01 times its radius. It is located 4446.78 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-175 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-175 b

Kepler-175 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 11.90 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-175.

The mass of Kepler-175 b is 9.15 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-175 b is 2.56 that of Earth. At 9.15 Earth masses, Kepler-175 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-175 c

Kepler-175 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.21 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 34.04 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-175.

The mass of Kepler-175 c is 14.59 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-175 c is 3.1 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-175 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-175, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
